Directly convert CH4 and CO2 into acetic acid is a 100 % atomic efficiency reaction, but remains a great challenge under mild conditions. Herein, we report that acetic acid is generated as the sole liquid product by direct CH4 and CO2 coupling over Pd/LDH catalyst by two stepwise technique at 200 °C and atmospheric pressure. The formation of acetic acid is closely related to the surface Pd0 content, as well as the number of medium-strong acid and medium-strong base on the catalyst surface. The results of in-situ DRIFTS experiments show that acetic acid is mainly formed by the coupling of CH3* and CO2* (CH3*+CO2*→CH3COO*+*), or via CH x * and COOH* coupling (CH x *+COOH*→CH x COOH*+*) to form acetate which then followed by hydrogenation reaction. In which CH3* is originated from CH4 dehydrogenation step, and COOH* may be formed by the reduction of CO2 on metallic Pd sites. This study provides a feasible approach for the construction of high selectivity catalytic materials for the direct co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 into acetic acid at low temperature. Introduction The rapid development of industrial technology and excessive consumption of fossil fuels have results in huge CO2 emissions, which have caused global environmental problems. Reducing the emission and rational utilization of CO2 contribute to establish carbon-neutral cycle. Therefore, enormous efforts have been devoted to convert CO2 into value-added chemicals or liquid fuels. Among them, CO2 hydrogenation is the most abundant and widespread [1]. However, this technology extremely relies on the production of "green hydrogen" which is derived from renewable energies such as wind or solar, and is hard to consume such a huge amount of CO2 [2]. Methane, the major component of natural gas, coalbed methane as well as shale gas, and is also a greenhouse gas. It is reported that its greenhouse effect is 25 times than that of carbon dioxide [3]. However, from a perspective of resource utilization, the two greenhouse gases are the most abundant and cheapest carbon resources in nature. The hydrogen-rich structure of CH4 can provide hydrogen source and energy for CO2 reduction. Direct co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 is an effective strategy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, recycling the carbon resource and reducing dependence on fossil resources. Currently, the most common technology for CH4 and CO2 co-conversion is through dry reforming to produce syngas which is then converted into various organic chemicals [4,5]. However, both the C-H bond in CH4 molecules and the C=O bond in CO2 molecules is difficult to activate, resulting in high temperatures of dry reforming (≥800 °C) and result in significant energy consumption [6]. Therefore, it is of great significant for developing a new technology that bypassing the syngas production step and directly converts CH4 and CO2 into value-added chemicals at low temperatures. CH3COOH as an important chemical, is mainly produced by carbonylation of methanol in industry involves using noble metal catalysts, corrosive HI and toxic CH3I [7,8]. Therefore, extensive efforts are focused on developing new catalytic systems to address these issues. In fact, the direct synthesis of acetic acid from CH4 and CO2 (CH4+CO2→CH3COOH) is a dream reaction for co-conversion of the two greenhouse gases. Unfortunately, the reaction is challenged by thermodynamic limitation. Studies have shown that the equilibrium conversion rate is only 1.6×10−6 even under harsh conditions (1000 K, 100 atm and 5 % CH4–95 % CO2) [9]. Nonetheless, it still attracted a large number of researchers due to its 100 % atomic efficiency and more environment-friendly process. Early studies mainly focused on homogeneous catalytic systems, using Pd(OAc)2 and Cu(OAc)2 as catalysts with K2S2O8/CF3COOH as solvents. The yield of acetic acid was 16.5 times than that of Pd molar mass [10]. Subsequent experiments demonstrated that the catalyst and K2S2O8 must coexist for occurring the reaction, and CF3COOH was found also be involved in the reaction to form acetic acid [11,12]. Considering the product separation and recycling of acetic acid from homogeneous systems, researchers have gradually shifted to heterogeneous catalysis in recent years. Active metals are mainly focused on Fe, Zn, Cu, and Pd, while molecular sieves (e.g., ZSM-5, MOR) and vacancy‐enriched oxides (e.g., TiO2, CeO2, ZrO2, and In2O3) are always selected as supports [13]. For instance, the reduced Pd-ZrO2 catalysts with larger Pd nanoparticle and oxygen vacancies generated in ZrO2, which enhanced the ability of CH4 dehydrogenation and C-C coupling for acetic acid formation [14]. Based on the investigations of CH4 dehydrogenation and CO2 hydrogenation reaction, our group proposed a two stepwise technique by alternative feeding of CH4 and CO2 between the cycles to give oxygenates [15]. Afterwards, a series of theoretical analyses and sufficient experiments were conducted to confirm the feasibility of this technique [16–18]. The key of this process is to overcome thermodynamic obstacle by release and supplied H2 in the separate steps. Recently, we have successfully constructed Zn-Ce/ZSM-5 catalysts and sole ethanol product was obtained by directly CH4-CO2 coupling under 150 °C [19]. The present of H2 in feed gas was also found to increase the number of CH x species, while H2O acted as protective agent to prevent the decomposition of the generated acetic acid and wash the generated products off from the catalyst surface. Up to now, the designing new catalytic materials simultaneously enhancing CH4 activation and CO2 insertion to improve acetic acid yield is the core of this reaction system. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) as a type of two-dimensional anionic clay materials, are formed by positively charged brucite intercalation, have received interests as candidate in heterogeneous catalysis [20]. LDHs materials are typical alkaline carriers, but trivalent cations such as Al3+in layers can also provide acid sites for catalytic functionality. Today, LDHs have been successfully applied in partial oxidation of methane and CO2 reduction [21,22]. Moreover, the structural advantages and special properties of LDHs provide the possibility for the direct synthesis of acetic acid from CH4 and CO2. Yu et al. [23] designed a Ni-based supported catalyst derived from LDH by a green hydrothermal strategy. It was found that the formation of CH3COOH is closely related to the surface active Ni0 content and the reducibility of the catalysts. The -OH group provided by the LDH ultrathin nanosheets could react with the activated CH x * radicals to form oxygenates at the interface. Additionally, CH4 and CO2 molecules could be activated on Pd site which was also favored for C-C coupling steps to form acetic acid. For example, Spivey and co-workers reported that Pd could activate CH4, CO2, and C2H4 by C-C coupling to produce C3 products such as propene, acetone and methyl acetate at 200 °C [24]. The addition of Pd to in catalysts was reported to decrease reaction temperature, and accelerated reaction rate as well as enhanced methanol selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction [25]. In this work, we synthesize a series of MgAl-LDH with different Pd contents for CH4 and CO2 co-conversion to acetic acid by two stepwise technique at 200 °C. Surprisingly, CH3COOH is found to be the only liquid product with a highest acetic acid yield of 61.8 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1 when Pd loading is 5wt. %. The characterization results indicated acetic acid formation is closely related to the surface Pd0 content, as well as the number of medium-strong acid and medium-strong base on the catalyst surface. In-situ DRIFTS experiments reveals acetic acid is mainly formed by the coupling of CH3* and CO2* (CH3*+CO2*→CH3COO*+*), or via CH x * and COOH* coupling (CH x *+COOH*→CH x COOH*+*) to form acetate which followed by hydrogenation to produce acetic acid. Experimental section Catalyst preparation MgAl-LDH supports were synthesized by a hydrothermal method. Typically, 6.1 g of MgCl2·6H2O, 1.5 g of AlCl3·6H2O and 4.3 g of CO(NH2)2 were dissolved in 30 mL deionized water with Mg/Al molar ratio of 5 and kept stirring for 30 min, Then, the solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 10 h. After cooled down to room temperature, the white precipitate was washed with deionized water for several times and dried at 70 °C for 12 h to obtain MgAl-LDH supports. The synthetic MgAl-LDH support was then dispersed in 600 mL of Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution with various mass fractions and stirred for 3 h. After washed with deionized water, it was further dispersed in 600 mL of NaBH4 (20 mM) solution under vigorous stirring for 1 h. Finally, the Pd/LDH catalyst was obtained after washing, drying at 50 °C for 12 h, and calcination at 150 °C for 3 h under Ar atmosphere. The catalysts were named as xPd/LDH (x = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9and 11 wt. %), according to the Pd content. Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on a Rigaku Smartlab under Cu Kα radiation (40 kV and 40 mA). The spectrum was collected in the range of 5°∼80° (2θ) at a rate of 4°/min. N2 adsorption was measured by Ouantachrome QDS-30 instrument. Before each measurement, all samples were pretreated in vacuum at 200 °C for 4 h, then the adsorption tests were carried out at -196 °C. The BET method was used to calculate the specific surface area, while pore sizes and pore volumes were achieved by the BJH method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a ThermoFischer ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a Mg Kα anode (1253.6 eV). The XPS peaks of Pd 3d spectra were calibrated by adventitious carbon C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. TEM images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-F200 instrument with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. The energy spectrum model was JED-2300T, with ethanol as a dispersant and ultrasonic treatment for 10 min. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on a TP-5080 chemical adsorption instrument equipped with a TCD detector. 0.05 g of sample was pretreated at 150 °C for 30 min in a N2 atmosphere (30 mL/min), and then cooled to 50 °C. After that, 5 % H2/N2 atmosphere was switched and the curve was recorded from 50 °C to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption measurement (NH3-TPD-MS) was also performed on the same equipment. 0.1 g of sample was pre-treated in He (30 mL/min) at 150 °C for 30 min. After cooling down to 50 °C, 1.0 % NH3/He mixture (30 mL/min) was switched to adsorb at 50 °C for 30 min. Then, He was purged for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed ammonia. Finally, desorption of ammonia was carried out in a flowing He by raising temperature to 700 °C, and the curve was detected using a Hyde QIC-20 mass spectrometer. CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD-MS) was conducted on the same procedure as that of NH3-TPD-MS. The only difference was that the CO2 signal was monitored. In-situ DRIFTS experiment was performed on a BRUKER INVENIO S spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector. Firstly, a certain amount of sample was loaded into an in-situ cell and pretreated in Ar atmosphere to remove moisture and impurities at 200 °C. After a background spectrum was recorded. Gaseous CH4 and CO2 were alternately introduced into the in-situ cell according to the set steps, and the spectrum was recorded every 5 min. The CO-DRIFTS test was performed on the same instrument. The spectral collection range was set to 400–4000 cm- 1 at a spectral resolution of 4 cm- 1 with 64 scanning time. The specific experimental procedures were as follows: Firstly, the sample was placed in an in-situ cell and heated to 50 °C in an Ar atmosphere for pretreatment. After that, the background spectrum was recorded. Then, the CO was flown into the cell to saturate. Finally, the spectrum was recorded in Ar flow every 5 min. The pyridine infrared experiment was carried out on the same equipment as the in-situ DRIFTS. Firstly, 0.02 g of sample was pressed and placed into a quartz cell for seal. After the vacuum degree reached to below 1×10- 2 Pa, the sample was pretreated by programmed heating to 350 °C for 1 h. Then, it was cooled to room temperature and collected the background, followed by pyridine adsorption saturation. When the vacuum degree was under 10- 2 Pa, the sample was heated to record the infrared spectrum at 150 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Catalyst evaluation The catalytic evaluation of CH4 and CO2 co-conversion to acetic acid was carried out in a self-designed device equipped with two fixed bed reactors (Fig. 1 ). Meanwhile, H2 and H2O was also added to the feed gas according to our previously study. Firstly, 0.25 g of catalyst (40∼60 meshes) was loaded in each reactor, then the temperature was raised up to 200 °C under N2 atmosphere. Afterwards, the mixtures of CH4+H2 +H2O (g) were introduced into the reactor A for CH4 dehydrogenation, while the mixtures of CO2+H2+H2O (g) were injected into the reactor B. After 200 s, CO2+H2+H2O (g) were switched into reactor A for coupling reaction, at this point, CH4+H2+H2O (g) were also switched into reactor B for CH4 dehydrogenation. After another 200 s, CH4, H2 and H2O (g) mixtures were re-entered into the A reactor, while CO2, H2 and H2O (g) mixtures were re-entered into the reactor B. As such, the stepwise technique was conducted continuously. The composition of the two mixtures was as follows: CH4 channel: Flow rate of CH4=50 mL/min, H2=5 mL/min, and H2O=0.2 mL/min. CO2 channel: Flow rate of CO2=50 mL/min, H2=20 mL/min, H2O=0.1 mL/min. The liquid product was collected after cooling and analyzed off-line by gas chromatography (HaixinGC-950). The product yield was calculated by the following equation: Y ( μ mol · g cat − 1 · h − 1 ) = A − b k × m M × 0 . 5 × 0 . 25 × 1 0 6 where A was the peak area of the product, m was the mass of the collected liquid phase, M was the molar mass of acetic acid, 0.5 and 0.25 was represented the catalyst mass (g) and reaction time (h), respectively. Results and discussion Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of Pd/LDH catalysts with different Pd loading were compared in Fig. 2A. As seen, the yield of acetic acid was only 38.4 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1 when Pd loading was 1wt. %. With the increase of Pd loading, the yield of acetic acid increased firstly and then gradually decreased to 44.0 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1. The highest acetic acid yield was achieved 61.8 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1 when the loading was 5.0 wt. %. It should be point out that acetic acid was the only liquid product, which was significant different from our previous results using TiO2 as carrier. This might be related to LDH carrier, which will explained in the subsequent discussion. Fig. 2B displayed the catalytic activity of 5Pd/LDH catalyst exposed in various atmosphere. As observed, the methanol was the sole product and its yield was only 3.3 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1 using CH4+H2+H2O as feed gas, probably originated from the CH4 oxidation by water, which also had been discovered by others [26,27]. For the use of CO2+H2+H2O as feed gas, only a trace amount of methanol with the yield of 1.4 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1 was detected, which might relate to the CO2 hydrogenation reaction and simultaneously excludes the possibility that acetic acid came from CO2 hydrogenation. Notably, the methanol yield decreased to 0.8 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1, while acetic acid was obtained when CH4+CO2 were co-fed, which strongly indicated that acetic acid was achieved by CH4-CO2 coupling reaction and simultaneously suppressing the formation of methanol. Nonetheless, the acetic acid yield remained relatively low at 14.4 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1, significantly lower than that achieved via the stepwise technique. This discrepancy could be attributed to the enhanced CH4 adsorption and dehydrogenation capacity inherent to the stepwise approach [19]. Furthermore, the stepwise strategy was found to promote C-C coupling reactions more effectively. These combined effects provided a plausible explanation for the exclusive detection of acetic acid in this reaction system. XRD characterization Fig. 3 displayed the XRD patterns of LDH support and different xPd/LDH catalysts. As shown, the support prepared by hydrothermal method exhibited typical characteristic diffraction peaks of hydrotalcite-like materials with the strong and sharp peaks at 2θ=11.5°, 23.5°, 34.9°, 39.2° and 47.1°, corresponding to the (003), (006), (012), (015) and (018) planes, respectively [28,29]. After PdCl4 2 - exchange, all diffraction peaks were still preserved well, suggesting that the LDH layered frameworks in the catalysts were intact. However, the intensities of these peaks became weaker, and further decreased gradually with the increase of Pd loading, meaning that the intercalation of Pd decreased the interlayer spacing of LDHs, which was ascribed to the substitution of interlayer anions and the destruction of hydrogen bonds [30]. Interestingly, a new diffraction peaks corresponding to (00l) plane appeared at 2θ=9.5° was observed, which indicated Pd species had successfully inserted into the LDH interlayer [31,32]. Meanwhile, an additional peak at 33.8° appeared after Pd loading, might be related to the (101) reflection of tetragonal PdO [33]. Also, it was noticed that the shoulder peak appeared near 2θ=39.3°, revealed the existence of Pd0 crystal plane (111), meaning the successful reduction of Pd species. The above results confirmed that both PdO and Pd0 species were existed in the catalyst. FT-IR study The FT-IR study was further employed to verify that PdCl4 2 - had been intercalated into LDH supporter. The broad peak centered at 3450 cm- 1 and 1630 cm- 1 were attributed to the symmetric stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups generated on LDH laminates and water molecules in interlayer, respectively [34]. The stretching vibration speaks at 2950 cm- 1 and 2839 cm- 1 corresponded to the C-H stretching vibration of the methoxy anion inserted in the LDH layer [35]. In general, the absorption bands at 1350 cm- 1∼1390 cm- 1 were usually attributed to interlayer ions, such as CO3 2- [32]. Obviously, the strong band centered at 1384 cm- 1 was corresponded to the ν1 vibration mode of CO3 2 - in LDH [28,32]. With regard to the Pd/LDH, the FT-IR spectra showed no obvious difference compared to that of original LDH, but the band strength of the CO3 2 - stretching vibration at 1384 cm- 1 reduced remarkably. Thus, it was deduced that PdCl4 2 - ions were partially intercalated into the interlayer of LDH supporter and replaced a part of CO3 2 - ions, which was consistent with the XRD analysis. The band at about 788 cm- 1 was assigned to the Al-O bond vibration and Al-O-H bending of AlO4 tetrahedron, respectively [34,36] Fig. 4 . N2 adsorption The specific surface area and pore size distribution of LDH supporter and Pd-contained catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption. As observed in Fig. 5 , the adsorption-desorption curves of each catalyst could be classified as type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loop patterns according to the IUPAC classification, which was a typical feature of mesoporous materials with slit shape pores formed by plate-like particles [37]. The LDH supporter displayed the minimum specific surface area (S BET) of 8.5 m2·g- 1(see Table 1 ). Interestingly, the S BET increased to 18.3 m2·g- 1 after Pd loading, and the value further raised to 25.0 m2·g- 1 with the increase of Pd loading. Meanwhile, the average pore sizes (D pore) of Pd/LDH catalysts decreased gradually, while the pore volumes were almost unchanged. Similar phenomenon was also reported by Feng et al. who believed it was mainly due to the formation of micro-crystallites after Pd loading [38]. The reducibility of pd/LDH catalysts To investigate the reduction behavior of the Pd/LDH catalysts, TPR tests were conducted. As displayed in Fig. 6 , the reduction profiles of all catalysts exhibited a broad reduction peak (peak β) in the temperature range of 200∼400 °C, which was assigned to the reduction of PdO nanoparticles strongly interacted with support [14,39]. Obviously, the peak area displayed an increasing trend with the increase of Pd loading, indicated that more amount of PdO species existed in the catalysts. Also, one could see that the reduction temperature gradually decreased with the increase of Pd loading. This was ascribed to the hydrogen spillover which contributed the reduction of PdO nanoparticles [14]. Additionally, a negative peak (peak α) near at 85 °C was assigned to the decomposition of PdH x induced by hydrogen spillover according to the literature [40]. In General, PdO x species could be readily reduced to metallic Pd by H2 at low temperatures, subsequently reacting with hydrogen to form PdH x species. Although the desorption area of peakα was relatively small, we still found that the amount of H2 consumption firstly increased and then decreased (see Table 1), with the 5Pd/LDH catalyst exhibited the maximum value, indicating a better redox property of the catalyst. Meanwhile, given that the CH4-CO2 coupling reaction was conducted at 200 °C, we proposed that this enhanced redox property might contribute to the improved catalytic activity. CO-DRIFTS CO was used as a probe molecule to verify Pd adsorption sites on LDH supporter at 50 °C. Thus, in-situ CO-DRIFTS experiments were performed and the result was presented in Fig. 7 . From high to low wavenumber, the characteristic peak at 2170 cm- 1 was attributed to PdO species with low-coordinated sites [41]. This peak was much weaker since CO adsorption on PdO was weaker than that of metallic Pd [42]. The peak at 2048 cm- 1 was most likely due to linear CO adsorption on relatively larger metallic Pd particles (∼20–30 nm), while the strong peak centered at 1935 cm- 1 and the range of 1900∼1800 cm- 1 was assigned to bridging and threefold sites adsorbed CO on metallic Pd sites [43,44]. The CO-DRIFTS results suggested that both PdO and metallic Pd co-existed in the catalysts. Additionally, it was observed that the 5Pd/LDH displayed the strongest peak of low-coordinated metallic Pd sites. Previously investigation reported that Pd species with more number of low coordination metallic Pd sites were more active than their fully coordinated counterparts or those in higher oxidation states, and the formed product was reported to desorb easily from the low-coordinated Pd sites because of the relatively low adsorption enthalpy [45,46]. Therefore, the increase number of low coordinated Pd0 sites in 5Pd/LDH catalyst might be one of the reasons for the better activity. XPS analysis The chemical state and surface elemental composition of Pd were investigated by XPS technique. Four deconvoluted peaks were identified in the spectral range, with corresponding fitting parameters summarized in Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 8A, the peaks observed at ∼ 335.2 eV and ∼340.4 eV were ascribed to Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2, respectively, exhibiting a characteristic spin-orbit splitting energy of ∼5.2 eV. The remaining two peaks centered at ∼337.1 eV and 342.3 eV were assigned to Pd2+ 3d5/2 and Pd2+ 3d3/2 [32,47]. These results suggested that some Pd species had been reduced to metallic Pd0 by NaBH4, accorded with the XRD, TEM and CO-DRIFTS results. Meanwhile, one could see that the peak of Pd 3d orbital signals gradually became prominent with the increase of Pd loading. Quantitative analysis revealed that the surface Pd0/(Pd2++Pd0) ratio firstly increased and then decreased (see Table 1), which was consistent with the variation of acetic acid yield (see Fig. 8B). Xiong et al. [48]. discovered that Pd0 species were contributed to CH4 activation and dehydrogenation to generate CH x using CH4 as the sole carbon source. The density functional theory study showed that the CH4 dehydrogenation activity on the (111) crystal plane of Pd would increase [49]. Hence, it was regarded that more amount of surface Pd0 was favors to the formation of acetic acid by dehydrogenation. TEM TEM measurement was conducted to investigate the distribution and mean size of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) in Pd/LDH catalysts. As shown in the Fig. 9 , it could be clearly observed that the Pd NPs were highly dispersed on the surface of the LDH. The average particle size of Pd nanoparticles showed a significant increasing trend, with average sizes of 3.4 nm, 4.9 nm and 5.4 nm, and a narrow distribution on the 1Pd/LDH, 5Pd/LDH, and 9Pd/LDH, respectively, suggested that higher Pd loading raised the growth and aggregation of Pd nanoparticles. In addition, both the lattice spacing of 0.20 nm and 0.23 nm assigned the PdO (101) facet and Pd (111) facet were identified [50], confirmed the coexistence of PdO species and metallic Pd species in the catalyst, which was align with the XRD, XPS and the NH3-TPD results. Acidic-Base properties In our previously study, both the amount of acidic and base was discovered to influence CH4-CO2 co-conversion [19]. Thus, TPD of CO2 and NH3 were conducted to investigate the acid-base properties of catalysts. From TPD profiles (Fig. 10 ), both basic and acidic sites were detected on the LDH support and Pd/LDH catalysts. As seen in Fig. 10A, the LDH support displayed two desorption peaks in the temperature range. After PdCl4 2 - ion exchange, all curves of Pd/LDH catalysts could be deconvoluted into three regions. The peak at about ∼150 °C (weakly basic sites) was associated with the OH- groups on catalyst surface. The region in the range of 200 °C∼450 °C (moderately basic sites) were related to oxygen in Mg2+-O2 - pairs, whereas the peak above 500 °C (strongly basic sites) corresponding to isolated O2 - anions [51]. Also, one could clearly see that the peak area varied significantly along with the increase of Pd loading. After calculation, the amount of CO2 desorption from these sites were displayed in Table 3 . It could be seen that the number of medium strong base sites first increased and then decreased after increasing Pd loading, while the number of weak basic sites almost unchanged. Among them, the 5Pd/LDH catalyst possessed the biggest number of medium strong base, which was consistent with the variation of acetic acid yield. According to the literature, both the weakly basic sites and moderately strong basic sites were favorable for CO2 adsorption, while the strong base site did not participate in the reaction [52,53]. Hence, it was believed that an appropriate amount of Pd loading preferentially locate on the moderately basic sites for improving the CO2 adsorption. It was generally believed that there was a linear correlation between the distribution of weak and medium strong bases and the CO2 conversion rate. This showed that the weak base and the medium strong base would affect the yield of acetic acid to a large extent. Wang et al. [54] reported that the synergistic effect of appropriate metal loading and LDH inherent basicity would promote the adsorption of CO2 molecules and subsequent activation. Hence, it was speculated that moderately strong basic sites played a key role in the coupling of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid. The acid sites of Pd/LDH catalysts were also visualized in Fig. 10B and the amount of acidity was summarized in Table 3. Only two types of acid sites were detected for the pure LDH supporter. For the Pd-contained catalysts, the NH3-TPD profiles could be deconvoluted into three Gaussian fitting desorption peaks, which were corresponded to weak acid sites, medium strong acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively. The weak acid sites came from the Brønsted acid site generated by the OH- group on the catalyst surface [55]. The medium strong acid sites ascribed to Lewis acid sites and strong acid sites were assigned to adsorb NH3 via N free electrons and catalyst surface metal Al3+coordination, respectively [56]. Notably, one could see that the number of weak acid sites and medium strong acid sites firstly increased and then decreased. Among them, the 5Pd/LDH also exhibited the maximum value. It was reported that the moderately L acid played an important role in light alkane dehydrogenation and the strength of Lewis greatly affected the activation of CO2 and the productivity of C2 products [57]. The Brønsted acid site was required for the hydrogenation of acetate in co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 [58]. Thus, the volcanic relationship between the number of medium acid sites and the formation rate of acetic acid was easy to understand. Afterward, the IR spectra of pyridine adsorption were conducted to study the type of acid sites. As observed in Fig. 10C, the peak at 1450 cm- 1 was attributed to the v (C-H) deformation vibration and v (C-C) vibration of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [59]. Also, it was clearly observed that the number of Lewis acid sites exhibited an initial increase followed by subsequent decrease with progressive Pd loading (Table 3). This phenomenon could be attributed to the formation of coordinatively unsaturated PdO x species during the loading process. The highly dispersed PdO x nanoparticles containing oxygen vacancies demonstrated strong interfacial interactions with the LDH support matrix, thereby generating additional Lewis acidic centers [60]. However, as evident by the TEM characterization, excessive Pd loading beyond optimal levels induced particle agglomeration, resulting in reduced dispersion efficiency and physical coverage of pre-existing acid sites on the support surface, which was consistent with the NH3-TPD results. Of course, it could be seen that there were certain difference in the acid content for the same catalyst obtained from the Py-IR and NH3-TPD results, but the variation trend was consistent, which was might due to the fact that Py-IR was a semi-quantitative characterization technique. Also, no B acid sites were detected in Py-IR tests, which could be attributed to two factors: (1) the relatively high pretreatment temperature (350 °C) resulted partial reduction of B acid sites; (2) the larger kinetic diameter of pyridine molecules likely hindered their diffusion into small pores within the catalyst and resulted in lower sensitivity of Py-IR characterization. Li et al. [61] reported that the Lewis acid facilitated to activate both CH4 and CO2 molecules to generate acetic acid. Therefore, it was speculated that the moderately strong acid sites induced by Lewis acid play a crucial role in CH4-CO2 coupling. Possible reaction mechanism of CH3COOH formation In order to further explore the reaction mechanism and potential reaction path of acetic acid synthesis from CH4 and CO2 over 5Pd/LDH catalyst, in-situ DRTFTS experiments were carried out to determine the possible intermediates. To eliminate the interference peaks generated by physical adsorption, all relevant spectra were collected after Ar purging. As shown in Fig. 11A, the bands centered at 2900 cm- 1–3200 cm- 1 were corresponded to gaseous CH4, while the broad peak in the range of 2200 cm- 1–2400 cm- 1 was belonged to gaseous CO2. In addition, one could see that when pure CH4 was introduced, the peaks at 2924 cm- 1 and 2863 cm- 1 attributed to the CH2* and CH3* intermediates were observed. Besides, a distinct peak of gaseous CO2 was also observed, implying that CH4 was easily over-oxidized to CO2 on Pd sites due to the thermodynamics favorable of CO2 formation [62]. These results strongly indicated that CH4 was dissociated on the Pd sites of catalyst surface. As for the pure CO2 feeding, two faint peaks attributed to the CO* near at 2120 cm- 1 and 2163 cm- 1 could be detected, suggested that CO2 could be reduced to CO by the reaction of CO2+H*→CO*+OH* on the Pd site to some extent. When both CH4 and CO2 feeding, all above discussed intermediates were still detected, suggested the two gases could be activated simultaneously. Afterward, Ar purge was performed to observe the dynamic variation of peaks for 5Pd/LDH catalyst using step-wise techniques. As shown in Fig. 11B, the peaks at ∼1478 cm- 1 and 1690 cm- 1 were corresponded to bicarbonates, while the peaks of 1434 cm- 1,1332 cm- 1 and 1513 cm- 1 were ascribed to monodentate carbonate, which might be formed by the reaction of CO2 with surface O species [63]. The peaks at 1369 cm- 1 and 1710 cm- 1 were belonged to the antisymmetric and symmetric OCO stretching vibration of the bidentate HCOO* species, which was closely related to the hydrogenation process of bicarbonate species [64]. In addition, the infrared signals at 1549 cm- 1 and 1620 cm- 1 were assigned to the COOH* group, which might be derived from CO2*+H*→COOH*+* or CO*+OH*→COOH*+*[65]. Importantly, the acetate CH3COO* species was detected at 1563 cm- 1 and 1723 cm- 1, indicating that the occurrence of C-C coupling via CH3* and CO2*(CH3*+CO2*→CH3COO*+*), or via CH x * and COOH* coupling (CH x *+COOH*→CH x COOH*+*). Conclusion In summary, a series of xPd/LDH catalysts with different Pd loadings were prepared by ion exchange method using LDH as support to investigate the coupling reaction of CH4 and CO2 by two stepwise techniques at 200 °C and atmospheric pressure. It was found that acetic acid was the only liquid product over Pd/LDH catalyst. Among them, the catalyst with 5 wt. % Pd loading obtained the highest acetic acid yield of 61.8 μmol·gcat - 1·h- 1. In addition, we discovered that the proportion of surface Pd0 was consistent with the variation of acetic acid yield. The incorporation of Pd in LDH supporter offers an excellent platform for affording appropriate amounts of medium strong acid and medium strong base sites, which also conducted to the activation of CH4 and CO2, thereby favoring acetic acid formation. In-situ DRIFTS experiments revealed that acetic acid was mainly formed by the coupling of CH3* and CO2* (CH3*+CO2*→CH3COO*+*), or via CH x * and COOH* coupling (CH x *+ COOH*→CH x COOH*+*) to form acetate which then followed hydrogenation reaction. In which CH3* was originated from CH4 dehydrogenation step, and COOH* may be formed by the reduction of CO2 on metallic Pd sites. coredata.dc:description: Directly convert CH4 and CO2 into acetic acid is a 100 % atomic efficiency reaction, but remains a great challenge under mild conditions. Herein, we report that acetic acid is generated as the sole liquid product by direct CH4 and CO2 coupling over Pd/LDH catalyst by two stepwise technique at 200 °C and atmospheric pressure. The formation of acetic acid is closely related to the surface Pd0 content, as well as the number of medium-strong acid and medium-strong base on the catalyst surface. The results of in-situ DRIFTS experiments show that acetic acid is mainly formed by the coupling of CH3* and CO2* (CH3*+CO2*→CH3COO*+*), or via CH x * and COOH* coupling (CH x *+COOH*→CH x COOH*+*) to form acetate which then followed by hydrogenation reaction. In which CH3* is originated from CH4 dehydrogenation step, and COOH* may be formed by the reduction of CO2 on metallic Pd sites. This study provides a feasible approach for the construction of high selectivity catalytic materials for the direct co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 into acetic acid at low temperature.
